alert.note: Alert for Elko (Nevada) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Advisory issued May 23 at 12:17PM PDT until further notice by NWS Elko
info.description: ...The Flood Advisory continues for the following rivers in Nevada... Humboldt River Above Carlin affecting Elko County. Lamoille Creek Above Lamoille affecting Elko County. Humboldt River At Palisade affecting Eureka County. Bruneau River At Rowland affecting Elko County. .Warm temperatures will continue to melt snowpack and slowly increase river flows. An active and wet pattern today and though the midweek could result in a rapid increase in levels and flows along the Humboldt River. For the Upper Humboldt...including Elko, Carlin...elevated river levels are forecast. For the Lower Humboldt...including Palisade, Battle Mountain, Comus...elevated river levels are forecast. For the Bruneau River...including Rowland...elevated river levels are forecast. ...FLOOD ADVISORY FOR SNOWMELT REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE... * WHAT...Flooding caused by snowmelt continues. An active and wet pattern brings high rainfall amounts today as well. * WHERE...Lamoille Creek Above Lamoille. * WHEN...Until further notice. * IMPACTS...At 4.0 feet, This is monitoring stage. Visitors to the lamoille canyon and the powerhouse picnic area need to use extreme caution around lamoille creek and other creeks in the ruby mountains. Pets, children, and even adult can be swept away in the strong current. At 4.8 feet, Flood stage at the powerhouse gage location in lamoille canyon. Minor flooding can occur in the town of lamoille. Water can seep into basements near the river. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:40 AM PDT Tuesday the stage was 4.5 feet. - Forecast...No forecast is available for this location. - Action stage is 4.0 feet. - Flood stage is 4.8 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: If you are in the advisory area, remain alert to possible flooding or the possibility of the advisory being upgraded to a warning. Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued Wednesday afternoon at 145 PM PDT.
